block.p: More Civilians Must Help In Iraq, U.S. Military Says Senior military officers have told President Bush and Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates that the new Iraq strategy could fail unless civilians step forward quickly to carry out plans for reconstruction and political development.

Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki acknowledged that his government had stumbled in its efforts to carry out a new security plan in Baghdad and that the delays and mounting violence were hurting its credibility with the Iraqi people.

Saudi Arabia Holds Peace Talks Leaders of the two main Palestinian parties, Hamas and Fatah, began a two-day Saudi-brokered effort to agree on a unity government that could end a wave of violence in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank.

Zimbabwe's Decline Quickens Zimbabwe's economy and quality of life of its citizens have been in decline for many years, but recent events, including the collapse of electrical service and an outbreak of cholera in the capital, have caused President Robert Mugabe to lose some support from his own party.
New U.S. Presence in Africa The Pentagon will establish a new military command to oversee its operations in Africa, President Bush said.

China and Global Warming China said wealthier countries must take the lead in curbing greenhouse gas emissions but did not say whether it would agree to any mandatory emissions limits that might hamper its booming economy.

NASA Astronaut Charged With Attempted Murder A NASA astronaut, Capt. Lisa Marie Nowak, has been charged with the attempted murder of a rival for the affections of a fellow astronaut. Police officials say Captain Nowak drove 900 miles from Texas to Florida and was found with a steel mallet, a knife, pepper spray, four feet of rubber tubing, latex gloves and garbage bags.
Army Phases In New Uniform The Army has been retiring its old starched and pressed Battle Dress Uniform in favor of a wrinkle-free cotton and nylon version.

Colleges Cater to Urban Appeal For decades, colleges in rural areas embraced a pastoral ideal, presenting themselves as oases of scholarship surrounded by nothing more distracting than lush farmland and rolling hills. But many officials at such institutions have decided that students today want something completely different: urban buzz.

New Tactic for Libby's Defense The jurors deciding the perjury case against I. Lewis Libby Jr. listened to his voice on audiotape for hours as his lawyers quietly explored a new strategy -- keeping him off the witness stand -- that would ensure that the jurors never hear his voice in person.

F.D.A. Approves Genetic Test A genetic test that tries to predict whether a woman with breast cancer will have a relapse won approval from the F.D.A., in a step toward an era in which medical treatments are ''personalized'' for each patient.

Competitors Line Up For Liberty Ferry Contract The National Park Service contract to run boats to Liberty and Ellis Islands, which expires on March 31, is up for bid for the first time in 18 years. Competitors are lining up for the first real chance to unseat the Circle Line, the only operator ferrying tourists to the islands, in more than 50 years.

Democrat Wins Senate Seat Craig M. Johnson, a Democrat, defeated Maureen O'Connell, a Republican, to win the costliest battle for a state legislative seat in New York history in a fight that became a test of Gov. Eliot Spitzer's political muscle.

Illinois Lands Top Recruits Illinois, one of the worst teams among the major conferences in college football in recent seasons, has astounded experts and enraged rivals by putting together one of the nation's best recruiting classes.

Allied Capital Under Inquiry Federal prosecutors have subpoenaed records of Allied Capital, a business development company, in an effort to discover how investigators hired by the company may have obtained the phone records of one of its leading critics.
Editorials: It's the war, senators; playing politics with justice; government inside out; Maura J. Casey on challenging the mullahs, one signature at a time.
Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Maureen Dowd.
